Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Collaborative Research: The Diffusion of State Policy Responses to the 2019 Novel Coronavirus

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration: When the 2019 novel coronavirus arrived in the United States in February and March of 2020, state governments quickly began enacting policies intended to contain and mitigate its spread. Understanding the timing and sequence of these policy choices, and those policies’ eventual consequences, is critical for assessing how governments can be most effective during pandemics. This project collects data on state and local governments’ responses to COVID-19, including policies related to closing schools, canceling travel, banning public gatherings, closing restaurants and bars, delaying rent payments, and rules on medical licenses. This data allows researchers to examine the factors that influence states’ policy choices, whether those factors differ from the ways in which states enact policies during normal times, which policies are effective in slowing the spread and morbidity of the virus, and how states roll back policies in a manner that allows economic activity to resume while maintaining preparedness to avoid and mitigated waves of the virus. <br/><br/>This project collects data on state government responses to COVID-19 by scraping government websites daily, focusing on sites dedicated to COVID-19 and those associated with the executive branch, state legislatures, and state departments of public health. It also collects data on the number of diagnosed cases, fatalities, recoveries in the states, and mobility data that tracks geographic movements from mobile phones. The policy recommendations or decisions recorded from state government pages include decisions related to closing schools, canceling travel, banning public gatherings (and their size), closing restaurants and bars, travel quarantines, postponing elections, safe shelter orders, limiting elective medical procedures, as well as when states modify these policies; additional data is collected from official state Twitter accounts. This data allows researchers to examine the factors that influence states’ policy choices, whether those factors differ from the ways in which states enact policies during normal times, which policies are effective in slowing the spread and morbidity of the virus, and how states roll back policies in a manner that allows economic activity to resume while maintaining preparedness to avoid and mitigated waves of the virus. <br/><br/>This project is jointly funded by the Accountable Institutions and Behavior Program and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project we conducted a national analysis, across the United States, of state-level responses to the COVID-19 pandemic. This was a collaborative project, conducted with partners at the University of Iowa, Notre Dame, and Penn State. In the component of the project that was led at Penn State, we focused on identifying and studying the public communications by U.S. state policymakers related to the pandemic. Since it is the most commonly used digital platform for broadcast-style communications, we focused on Twitter. We constructed a database covering state policymakers' Twitter accounts, collected their communications on Twitter, and studied the nature of those communications.


Our primary findings centered around the ways policymakers communicated about the pandemic. We found that they emphasized the public health and business/economic impacts, with Democrats focusing more on the former and Republicans more on the latter. We also found that state policymakers were largely responsive to the severity of the pandemic in their states, with increases in cases and deaths driving higher amounts of online attention. They were also more likely to discuss the pandemic online when their states were engaging in policymaking efforts related to the pandemic. The degree to which policymakers' pandemic-related communications depended on pandemic indicators and policymaking efforts depended on their partisanship. 


The broader impacts in this project were three-fold. First, we provide data that will be used in future research, and by other scientists. Second, we provided training and research experience to one undergraduate student and two graduate students who were employed on this project. Third, we provide insights into the ways that states policies and policymakers respond to a public health crisis, which will be valuable in approaching future public health emergencies.
